copenhagen's popular market place torvehallerne is the best place to look for danish delicacies, local vegetables, fresh fish, or maybe some italian specialities. torvehallerne were designed by architect hans hagens and opened in september 2011. one of the key points of torvehallerne is that they specialise in selling some of the freshest products that arenâ€™t often found in â€˜run-of-the-millâ€™ markets. one of the best surprises about torvehallerne is that it actually has two main halls specialising in different types groceries, small restaurants, take out places, kitchen knickknacks or the most precious of nectars - wine!

good morning copenhagen. torvehallerne is a buzzing food hall smack-bang in the city centre of copenhagen. close to the busy nÃ¸rreport street and the pristine lakes, itâ€™s the perfect place where you can grab a handful of delicious treats to watch the sun go down on popular dronning louises bridge. torvehallerne is not a supermarket - it is a super market. at this beautiful food market, you will find over 60 stands selling everything from fresh fish and meat to gourmet chocolate and exotic spices, as well as small places where you can have a quick bite to eat.

major throwback to 2011 when i visited copenhagen for a few days. my friend asked for some tips for cph but since i hadn't been in such a long time, i didn't feel comfortable suggesting places as they may be totally crap now and/or have shut down. so, i went on a google rampage and pulled a list together (like i normally would whenever i go on holiday) of places i'd like to stay, eat (most important ğŸ˜), get lashed and grab some culture. having done this list, i am now majorly craving a revisit to copenhagen, mostly because the restaurant scene seems so insanely amazing. beyond geranium and noma, there seems to be a whole stable of exciting eateries with talented chefs, working both in the fine dining world and street food scene, many of whom are alumini of renÃ© redzepi, like girl boss rosio sanchez, his ex pastry chef - who went off to create her own taqueria, so the danes could experience proper tacos - err body deserves tacos afterall - basic human right if you ask me. full deets live on the blog and there's a map ğŸ—º too. also, if anyone has their own tips, please do share!

last year i made a foodie pilgrimmage to copenhagen a place which has to be near the top of any foodies travel list. copenhagen of course is awash with michelinstar restaurants and much like in the past when i got my picture taken at many a famous monument this picture for me outside noma was the equivalent of the picture i had in italy at the trevifountain or the spanishsteps at 21 and equally as exciting, oh how my world has changed. ğŸ˜†ğŸ¤ now i don't have a michelin star budget so i never got to dine at noma but i didn't miss out because copenhagen has some fantastic markets, torvehallerne is a rival to the englishmarketcork, there is the disney land of food tourism experiences at on papiroen beside and endless food experiences at the meat packing district. with organic food and sourdough products everywhere. i even had organic sourdough pizza at mothercopenhagen now that's what i'm talking about. i have tonnes of footage, from which i'm fashioning a youtube video but i am going to start instagramming some of the content so stay tuned and follow this feed if it is of interest to you.ğŸ˜†ğŸ‘ğŸ‘ vistcopenhagen tasteofireland danishfood denmark irishblogger irishfoodbloggers irishfoodblogger copenhagen

my favourite place in the city has to be the torvehallerne; a buzzing food market set within two glass houses. one half houses the rawer of ingredients; fresh fish on ice, local meats and cold cuts, bread, cheese and there is a nut stall i am rather fond of which does spectacular things like chocolate coated pecans and walnuts. over in the other glass house sit the cafes and lunch-time places; there is a popular porridge spot in the corner, a very good coffee stall, about three places that serve glugg (mulled wine but richer in nordic spice), half a dozen vibrant sandwich and salad stalls and a constantly busy fish cake stand offering wooden spoons of the delicious stuff dipped in fresh tartar sauce. after sampling one of everything we settled on two boxes of the brightest salads made with locally sourced ingredients, a whole smoked mackerel and two thick slices of nutty rye. . . . . cophenhagenlife copenhagen hygge torvehallerne travelphotography travelersnotebook lifeslittlestories landandsea lifeandthyme theartofslowliving momentsofmine foodstyling thatsdarling verilymoment momentsofmine darlingweekend darlingmovement darlingdaily theprettycities photostory photoessay keepitwild sustainableliving welivetoexplore behomefree slowmorning onthetable gatheringslikethese forahappymoment instafood

copenhagen's popular market place torvehallerne is the best place to look for danish delicacies, local vegetables, fresh fish, or maybe some italian specialities. torvehallerne were designed by architect hans hagens and opened in september 2011. one of the key points of torvehallerne is that they specialise in selling some of the freshest products that arenâ€™t often found in â€˜run-of-the-millâ€™ markets. one of the best surprises about torvehallerne is that it actually has two main halls specialising in different types groceries, small restaurants, take out places, kitchen knickknacks or the most precious of nectars - wine!

good morning copenhagen. torvehallerne is a buzzing food hall smack-bang in the city centre of copenhagen. close to the busy nÃ¸rreport street and the pristine lakes, itâ€™s the perfect place where you can grab a handful of delicious treats to watch the sun go down on popular dronning louises bridge. torvehallerne is not a supermarket - it is a super market. at this beautiful food market, you will find over 60 stands selling everything from fresh fish and meat to gourmet chocolate and exotic spices, as well as small places where you can have a quick bite to eat.

it was the very late fall when the nansen collided against the rocks of what is now the financial district. the crew of 26 survived the disaster but their supplies were washed away as the wreck crumpled into the waters and was swept away. the men would not have likely escaped the fate of their vessel had it not been for the appearance of an enormous porcine monster, buoyant in the waves because of bladders of unctuous fat that folded over it as protection against the cold. the sailors clung to the creatureâ€™s skin as it floated to shore. it good naturedly let them down and plopped down for a rest itself. at which point the explorers fashioned a huge stake out of a large log, attached their swords and knives to it to create a giant harpoon to kill their benefactor as it slept. they roasted it, ate it over weeks, turned its fat into candles and fuel, and its skin into tents and warm clothing. they used its huge bones and horns to build the entrance of their settlement, eventually called nansensgate. this was the first thanksgiving on the island. â€” from â€œa praeternatural history of manhattan.â€ ( idrawinrestaurants hcegoestocph)

torvehallerne, copenhagen, denmark: a great produce and food market. an essential stop for anyone who loves eating and cooking. the market offers a wide variety of things: bakery, coffee, beer, wine, seafood, butcher shop, cookware (selling mainly de buyer pans), kitchen knife (mainly japanese brands), pretty much anything you can think of. you can spend an entire morning here, strolling around, and grabbing a few bites here and there.

i've thought a lot this trip about why people travel, and the value you can gain from it. one of the biggest things for me is seeing that no matter where you go, people tend to look for the same simple pleasures in life. a good cup of coffee, a good book, spending time with friends & family, meeting new friends, seeing historic places, exploring nature - we are more alike than we are different.

bloom where you are planted! and i am so proud to say that i was partially planted here. this morning i took the plane to copenhagen and i really love this town. i feel so connected to the people and the mood here. my mother was born in denmark but has lived in sweden her whole grown up life, but we spent endless summers in denmark when i was little and i have also studied here. i feel much like a dane at heart, there is so much to love here, people, architecture, food, design, beer and much more. today i have been wandering the streets and enjoying the beautiful life here, and tomorrow i'm so excited to join a course with _milk and two amazing ladies that i have followed for such a long time! and i look forward to meet and there as well, who else is coming? visitcopenhagen hotelsp34 alliseeispretty

when traveling i prefer outdoor markets to restaurants most of the time because they're less expensive, have a wide variety of foods to choose from, and can be eaten on the go which is handy when trying to pack in a full itinerary. this market called torvehallerne has it all and is located conveniently just south of the botanical gardens, rosenburg slot (castle) and smk museum... all of which were on the day's docket. naturally i scarfed down a danish cinnamon roll (mmmmmm) and americano and picked up a lox salmon sandwich for lunch later. bonus: look at the purrrrty flowers! i was tempted to pick up a bouquet even though that would have been ridic to carry around all day. ğŸ’ . . . traveloften travelgram flowerstagram visitdenmark visitcopenhagen charming
